items.title: Equanimity
items.content_html:
In the most recent issue of my newsletter, I linked to a post on Maria Popvaâ€™s The Marginalian, titled â€˜The Stoic Key to Kindnessâ€™. It’s a piece that has stuck in my mind since I first read it, and in particular this quote from Marcus Aurelius’s Meditations:

Suppose someone standing by a clear, sweet spring were to curse it: it just keeps right on bringing drinkable water bubbling up to the surface.

Popovaâ€™s focus here (and Aureliusâ€™s) is on the necessity for kindness, even in the face of adversity. As Iâ€™ve grown older, Iâ€™ve become increasingly convinced that kindness is indeed the most valuable characteristic one can foster, both in oneself and in others. But, the piece also speaks directly to something broader that Iâ€™ve considered a development goal for myself for many years: equanimity.

One of the first concepts from Buddhist thought that I remember encountering was fudÅshin, the idea that to approach some things as â€˜positiveâ€™ and others as â€˜negativeâ€™, is in-and-of-itself an unskilful practice. By thinking of things in this manner, we are going some way towards pre-determining our response to them. We think hanging out the laundry is boring, and thus prime ourselves to approach the task with the expectation that we will be bored doing it; we would rather be doing something else.

I fail at this all the time. All too easily, I find myself separating my day into â€˜things I want to doâ€™ and â€˜things I donâ€™t want to doâ€™. Listen to that new record; make a cup of coffee; watch a movie â€” these are things I naturally approach with a positive mindset. Doing the dishes; cardio workouts; even small things like shaving â€”Â I routinely catch myself approaching these tasks with a negative mindset. My unexamined predisposition in these moments is to consider these things â€˜obligationsâ€™, and thus â€˜things I donâ€™t enjoy doingâ€™. That reflexive response, however, sets me up for a negative experience each time.

Equanimity, as I think of it, is the quality of approaching all things with a neutral, open mind. Rather than letting any predisposition colour the experience (one way or the other), being present with whatever activity one is currently engaged in. There is another relevant concept from Buddhism here: shoshin, â€˜the beginnerâ€™s mindâ€™. This is the idea that it is skilful to approach all tasks with the open mind of a beginner, attentive to nuances and possibilities, rather than the comparatively closed mind of an expert, for whom many things are pre-decided. I might think that, since I have hung out the laundry hundreds of times, I know all there is to know about hanging out laundry. And one thing I know for certain, is that doing so is boring. To approach any task in this frame of mind is to pre-determine that youâ€™re definitely going to have a bad time. There is value in approaching all things, as though you are eager to learn.

items.content_html:
This week a leaked draft opinion from the US Supreme Court made more likely the prospect of widespread banning of abortions across the country. The news shaped a lot of what I’ve been reading and watching lately, and in this weekend’s issue of Tendrils I’m going to be sharing notes on some fiction and documentary films I watched. I also wanted to make space to share some links to, and excerpts from, the best pieces of journalism I read on the topic:

  • â€™The Limits of Power in a Post-Roe Worldâ€™ by Rebecca Traister in the May 9-22, 2022 issue of New York magazine

the reasoning behind abortion bans is a lie. Bans do not stop abortions from happening. Rather, they are meant to punish people for asserting control over their bodies, lives, and families, and the people who get punished more cruelly and regularly in this country have always been people who are not white and not wealthy

  • â€™The anti-abortion movement is about to win. Even it isnâ€™t ready for what comes nextâ€™ by Anna North in issue #37 of The Highlight

â€œIt is this same groups of people who are surveilled, suspected, targeted by law enforcement in all realms of their life, who are the ones who are going to be disproportionately criminalized for self-managing abortion,â€ Adams said. That includes â€œBlack, Indigenous and other people of color, immigrants, trans and gender non-conforming folks, and certainly people living in poverty, as well as people living in rural areas and young people.â€

  • â€™Abortion has been treated as a fringe issue by Democrats for decades. This is the resultâ€™ by Anna North for Vox

The marginalization of abortion in Democratic politics is at least as old as Roe v. Wade. The 1973 decision, which established a constitutional right to an abortion, may have given liberals a false sense of security, Goodwin said. â€œThere was a confidence that the United States was a country that would not roll back, and that would not reach back to its worst tendencies.â€ It wasnâ€™t just Roe. Americans had also seen the recent gains of the civil rights movement, including the Voting Rights Act and integration of schools, after brutal and sometimes bloody fights. There was â€œthis sense that we can breathe now in the 1970s,â€ Goodwin said, â€œthat now we can say weâ€™ve learned from these horrors of the past and that we will not take lightly what respecting equality truly means under this flag.â€

  • â€™What the U.S. Could Learn from Abortion Without Bordersâ€™ (by Anna Louise Sussman for The New Yorker) centres around comparison with a European assistance network that works to help people seeking abortions in countries such as Poland (where abortion was made illegal in 1993)

What seems unusual about Abortion Without Borders is that it combines highly visible advocacy, logistical support for abortions, and funding from major N.G.O.s and governments

  • â€™The end of Roe will mean more children living in povertyâ€™ by Dylan Scott for Vox:

The children born in these circumstances will start life a few steps behind, all because their political leaders strove to ban abortion without offering support to the children who would be born if their aims were achieved.

  • â€™Abortion Bans Are Disregarding the Lives of Sexual Assault Survivorsâ€™ by Kylie Cheung for Jezebel

The landmark Turnaway Study on the impacts of being unable to access abortion care found that being forced to keep an unwanted pregnancy significantly increases the risk of being entrapped in an abusive relationship. Another study found nearly a tenth of people who seek abortion care are trying to end their pregnancies because they have abusive partners. Fifteen percent of women experiencing intimate partner violence reported that their partners also subjected them to reproductive coercion.

Finally, Iâ€™d also recommend episode 48 of the Strict Scrutiny podcast â€” â€˜Whatâ€™s Next in a Post-Roe Worldâ€™ â€” a conversation between Supreme Court watchers, legal scholars, and a professor of Obstetrics, Gynecology & Reproductive Sciences.

items.title: On the Commodification of Art
items.content_html:
In the latest issue of his excellent newsletter, Culture: An Ownerâ€™s Manual, W David Marx lays out the evolution of thinking around the place of art within culture vis-Ã -vis money. Whilst his argument is focussed on the visual arts, reading it made some related ideas click into place for me.

As it has evolved over the last decade or so, there has been a particular aspect of culture that Iâ€™ve felt especially repelled by: a steadily increasing comfort with, and latterly widespread embrace of, the commercialisation and commodification of art. As a cynical member of Gen X, who thought the height of cool was Nirvana refusing to mime on Top of the Pops, and Kurt Cobain wearing a â€˜Corporate Magazines Still Suckâ€™ t-shirt on the cover of Rolling Stone, perhaps I’m particularly primed to find this sad and irksome. Nevertheless, few things bug me more than the willingness (even eagerness) to subvert and distort the authentic self, and genuine art, in service of popularity and monetary gain.

Iâ€™m a middle-aged man â€”Â I should be irritated by a mainstream culture predominantly aimed at younger generations. But isn’t it supposed to be because young people are being thoughtless, are acting reckless, and have a shocking lack of respect for prior generations' culture? Instead the whole landscape seems to be awash with branded influencer opportunities on Instagram, and dreams of a career generating subscription revenue for Amazon, whilst shilling energy drinks.

It’s not fair to lay all of this at Gen Z’s feet: NFTs (the latest, most crass, and most thoroughly meritless commodification in the name of art) are largely not their fault. I think partly I’m just cranky that everything went this way. To an increasing extent, as we progressed into the 21st century, culture moved online, and online became culture. The creeping commercialisation and centralisation of that space necessarily resulted in similar mutations in art & culture. W David Marx’s argument feels especially sound to me in that respect: we moved from an avant-garde that believed â€˜true art can’t be commercializedâ€™, via a series of hops, to a modern era in which â€˜monetization is the cultureâ€™. Heck, you can even buy a copy of that t-shirt for $550.

Marxâ€™s newsletter is consistently great; you can read past issues, and sign up for it, here.

items.title: Loveable Losers Once More?
items.content_html:
Thereâ€™s a sense in which the Cubs not being remotely competitive this season leads to a real reduction in stress when watching these games. It feels a little like a return to the loveable losers kind of baseball that weâ€™re used to watching, with the year-after-year post-season contention being the anomaly. In that respect, weeks of losing baseball kind of blurs together, and Iâ€™m just able to enjoy the occasional high point here and there. I feel less down about series losses, and still excited by individual excellent performances, or even just great plays.

Case in point: yesterdayâ€™s game against the Padres was a lot of fun. A 6-0 win, with Hendricks looking pretty much as good as it gets: three hits through 8.2. Heyward had a nice game, as did Gomes, and so too did Nico â€” I love to see some aggressive base running, and he generated a run in the 8th.

It just goes to show: thereâ€™s still plenty of fun to be had when the teamâ€™s not exactly where youâ€™d like them to be. Heck, the White Sox have a record .143 better at the moment, but their fans were probably pretty unhappy last night.

items.title: A Memoir Blue
items.content_html:
Over the weekend I played through A Memoir Blue, a short ‘interactive poem’ from Cloisters Interactive. Its combination of relatively light interactivity, with a focus on telling a personal story, reminded me of titles like ustwo’s Assemble With Care, and the superb Florence by Mountains (with which A Memoir Blue shares a publisher in Annapurna Interactive).

I found a lot to like in the magical realist tone, and the really effective manner in which it’s conjured through the mixing of two distinct animation styles. Both the 3D models and the hand-drawn animated characters are imbued with an impressive sense of personality. But, just as impressive, the world of the story is brought to life with charming detail and a really effective sense of material weight, which is far easier experienced than it is described.

A Memoir Blue is available now on consoles & PC, with a future release planned for iOS.

items.title: Momento Mori
items.content_html:
The first thing I see when I open my eyes in the morning depends upon which way I’ve rolled during the night. If I wake up laying on my right side, I open my eyes to see my partner; if I’ve rolled left, the first thing I see is this:

This little tableau features a small metal Buddha, serving as both a hook for a rosewood mala, and a prop to keep a postcard upright. It’s the postcard I want to talk about: I picked it up at Ai Weiwei’s show at the Royal Academy in 2015; it shows his triptych ‘Dropping a Han Dynasty Urn’ (1995). Here’s a better look at the artwork:

Much of the commentary around this piece focusses on the (seven figure) value of the urn in question, but for my purposes it could just as easily have been an entirely unremarkable, mass-produced ceramic vase. I use this postcard as a daily reminder of impermanence. Looking at it, I imagine that the first image of the triptych represents my waking moments, with the day ahead. The day itself will be the second image: suspended in air, but in motion. The third image is inevitable:Â it’s the night that will arrive to close the day out. I find it useful to be reminded that each day passes like this, and that we experience time in one direction only. Once night arrives, you can no more return to the day than the urn can spring into the air, un-shattered.

And it’s not just days, of course â€” this is also the manner in which our lives pass. I’m publishing this today as it happens to be the fourth anniversary of my mother’s death. Perhaps unsurprisingly, that event itself remains the most powerful example in my life that everything is impermanent. This idea is also at the center of the Buddha’s teaching, which is how I know he doesn’t mind propping up the postcard. I understand that the very idea of momento mori can provoke a reflexive flinch â€“Â the mind does not want to ponder its own extinguishing â€” but I find value in having this metaphor at hand as a reminder. Whatever the day holds, it is unique and it is transient, and it is worth being present for. (I feel the same way if I wake facing the other direction.)
